data.title: This window is no longer responsive (on paste of 300 lines)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.10586]

This is more of a crash report than a bug report. Perhaps it should be a feature request for optional automated crash reporting...?

I have a Node JS project open, running smoothly for a week or so, loving the editor.

7 'working files', all small.

Pasted 350-odd lines of console output into a new, blank document, and the workspace window went blank (background colour) and all (pasted) text vanished. 

The whole program became unresponsive.

A dialog opened: 'This window has become unresponsive.'  Close or wait? Wait.

The dialog re-opened: 'This window has become unresponsive.'  Close. 

Please find a copy of the pasted text (saved via Sublime....!)

[dump2+.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/195002/dump2.txt)

data.title: Code folding does not appear if code is not properly formatted
Global envvars overwrites process.env only when there's no terminal attached.
data.body:
fixes #4779

Sometimes users want to launch `code` from terminal after
modifying environment variables.
When `code` is launched from terminal, it respects those modifications.

data.title: Debugger is throwing error while trying to run prelaunch task from launch.json.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: Windows10
  Setup:
  Launch.json:
  "program": "${workspaceRoot}/app.js",
          "preLaunchTask": "build",

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a Typescript node.js console app in Visual studio.
2. Launch VS code and open root directory.
3. Configure task.json with below entries and refer created task into launch.json.
      {
        "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "tsc",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "args": [],
    "showOutput": "always",
    "tasks": [
        {
            "taskName": "build",
            "isBuildCommand": true,
            "args": ["app.ts"],
            "problemMatcher": "$tsc"
        }
    ]
}
4. Start debugger and verify output.

Actual:
1. Getting error pop-up and error message contents in output window is not matching with actual error.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14128536/97034ce2-f5d6-11e5-9a45-b92754bb5066.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14128405/80568604-f5d5-11e5-95e7-031decc7722b.png)
2. Getting error pop-up for preLaunchTask and when user click on continue everything works perfectly.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14128484/1574f37e-f5d6-11e5-892d-6c15e9f87153.png)
3. Looks like task got failed but .js file generated successfully.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14128388/520d7f6e-f5d5-11e5-8008-f5829225c2e5.png)
4. Sometime showing multiple error messages in the output window.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14128422/af89af96-f5d5-11e5-8a75-01bb3f0d7fdd.png)

data.title: Documents created in VS Code don't appear in Open Recent

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Windows 7 

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a new file, save, and close.
2. Navigate to File > Open Recent. The newly-created file is not shown. Opening a second time  will cause it to be shown.

I may be pedantic, but this seems unintuitive.

data.title: Adding node_modules folder to .vscode directory causes hang
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: Ubuntu 15.10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a Node.js project
2. If you haven't already, run npm install to generate the files under node_modules
3. In VS Code drag the node_modules directory to move it under .vscode directory
4. Wait a few seconds then the window will hang.

data.title: [Linux] Rearranging working files with a long path shows white box
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha or 0.10.13-insiders
- OS Version: Ubuntu 15.10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Add keybindings.json to your working files
2. Grab the file and drag it, as if you were going to rearrange the working files.

Actual:
Shows a white bar off the right of the file name since the path is too long. It appears that the length of the bar is related to the length of the full path.
![workingfilesarrange](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12900364/14125107/3dada77c-f5be-11e5-9425-05d2526df825.png)

data.title: Cannot pass environment variable that is already defined in shell's rc file.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Export a variable in your default shell  (`~/.zlogin` for zsh;  `~/.bash_login` for bash, for example. You can use `.bashrc` as well).
   
   ``` sh
   export FOOBAR="1"
   ```
2. Pass different value of the same variable to VSCode.
   
   ``` sh
   FOOBAR=2 code .
   ```
3.  VSCode uses value defined for login shell, not current session: 
   
   Help > Toggle Developer Tools. And in Console,  `process.env.FOOBAR`  gives "1"  when I expect "2".

It looks like VSCode executes default shell as login shell again before launching the program UI.

Being able to pass different values for existing environment variables greatly helps writing/testing extensions.

Related discussion:  https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go/issues/220#issuecomment-203092824
###### strace example:

``` sh
$ strace -E GOPATH=1 -E FOOBAR=2 -s 1000000 -e verbose=execve -e abbrev=none ./.build/electron/electron  .
execve("./.build/electron/electron", ["./.build/electron/electron", "."], [... "GOPATH=1", ...]) # What I expected
...
read(62, "...\nGOPATH=/home/saml/go\n....")  # What is this?
...
```

data.title: Can't column select first character on a line if drag left
data.body:
- VSCode Version:0.10.13 insiders
- OS Version:Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a file with characters without indenting
2. Set cursor to the right and try to column select moving mouse to the left
   You can't select the first characters on lines.
   You can select the first characters if you start on the first character and move the mouse to the right.

data.title: Python hangs on timer.sleep in while loop
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.4 (15E65) and Windows 10
- Python Version: 2.7.11

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Use this .vscode/tasks.json

```
// A task runner that calls the Typescript compiler (tsc) and
// Compiles a HelloWorld.ts program
{
    "version": "0.1.0",

    // The command is tsc. Assumes that tsc has been installed using npm install -g typescript
    "command": "python",

    // The command is a shell script
    "isShellCommand": true,

    // Show the output window only if unrecognized errors occur.
    "showOutput": "always",

    // args is the HelloWorld program to compile.
    "args": ["${file}"]
}
```
1. Run this python code in VS Code

```
import time

x = 0
while x < 3:
    print "hello"
    x += 1
    time.sleep(1)
```

This will not print anything, and the VS Code will hang

(3.) This will work:

```
import time

x = 0
while x < 3:
    print "hello"
    x += 1
```

> hello
> hello
> hello

data.title: Errors appear multiple time in the Errors and Warnings window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise

The button in the status bar says 2 errors 0 warnings which is correct. The popup shows a lot of times the same 2 errors. There is some disconnect there.

Steps to Reproduce:
I'm not sure how to reproduce it, although I'm guessing that the fact that my build task was a "watch" and it was giving the same errors multiple times helped.
I'm using this project: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-react-native although those particular changes aren't on mainline yet.

The last part of the output was:
src\extension\commandPaletteHandler.ts(32,68): error TS2346: Supplied parameters do not match any signature of call target.

data.title: Add extension deprecation and redirection
data.body:
Allow extensions to specify they are deprecated in their `package.json`, with an optional alternative extension(s) field. This setting can inform the user of the deprecation in-product, and if specified, potentially update to the new extension automatically without informing of the deprecation?

Related: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/3670

data.title: Inconsistent shortcut key translations

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10 / Ubuntu 15.10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Change to another language, I used Spanish.
2. Hover over the Explorer/Search/Git/Debug icons on the left

Actual:
It is translating the shortcut word Shift. Elsewhere, such as the file menu, it is not translated.

data.title: Fuzzy search to open file doesn't show most relevant suggestion first
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Windows 8.1

![fuzzy](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/163637/14121605/7c85ea38-f5f8-11e5-8d02-cd2d1bd2f297.png)
As you see in the image, I've searched for `overlay/index` but the file I'm looking for is not the first suggestion even if there is only one file whose path fully matches what I've written. Changing `/` to `\` doesn't seem to matter.

Both Atom and Sublime have really great implementations of this, would be great to have it in VS Code as well.

data.title: [c++] C & C++ Syntax Highlighting Issues

milestone.title: April 4th Insiders
milestone.description: Issue to be included in the April 4th Insiders update.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Windows 7
## Issue 1:

In the following code (using C++ syntax highlighting), the string literal(s) are not highlighted at all.
This issue is exclusive to C++ syntax highlighting and does not occur with C syntax highlighting.
#### Code:

```
int main()
{
    printf("%s\n", "a string");
}
```
#### Result

![Bug Screenshot](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/SE2Dev/VSCode-BugExample/master/resources/c-vs-cpp.png)
## Issue 2:

In custom tmLanguage based colorizers that reference source.c from within rules that begin with certain patterns, the inlined C highlighting is incorrect (this issue also applies to rules using source.c++ but does not occur in rules using source.js).
#### Code

(See https://github.com/SE2Dev/VSCode-BugExample)
#### Result

![Bug Screenshot](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/SE2Dev/VSCode-BugExample/master/resources/screenshot.png)

data.title: Error count is not showing up in the status bar when building TypeScript node.js project.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: WIndows10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a TypeScript->Node.js->BlankConsoleApp in Visual Studio.
2. Launch VSCode and open project folder.
3. Configure tasks.json by selecting typescript setting.
4. Keep the default setting for tasks.json and compile the project with: CTRL+SHIFT+B.
5. Verify error message in the output window and status bar.

Actual: Status bar is showing 0 error.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14121212/5489b804-f5ab-11e5-82a3-b9130e76bb76.png)

data.title: Not getting intellisense for predefined common variables in task.json and launch.json.
data.body:
- VSCode Version:0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: windows10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch app and open any folder which contains .ts project
2. Add task.json file or select the node.js environment to generate launch.json.
3. Try to update the property value with predefined common variables like ${file},${cwd}, ${workspaceRoot} etc. in task.json or launch.json .
4. Verify intellisense should display for all the predefined common variables.

Actual: Intellisense is displaying only for ${workspaceRoot}.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14119581/a96818e6-f5a3-11e5-8b51-2a92289e769e.png)

Thanks in advance

data.title: Warn the user if Code is run as root
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce:

I have installed VSCode via the regular installer on OS X. I accidentally used VSCode in a sudo terminal session. Since then, I cannot install any plugins anymore. I have removed the `~/.vscode` and `~/Library/Application Support/Code`, but no luck. Reinstalling VSCode doesn't help :(

When I try to install an extension, the blue bar below the 'ext install' textbox just keeps moving, without showing any extension. When I run it from a root session, then it works fine and all the extensions show up.

data.title: [scss] intellisense doesn't work with nested properties

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.title: Navigate the folder explorer by typing folder name

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Similar to how file explorers/tree views work on most platforms, it would be convenient to be able to navigate through the folder explorer using a-z. For example:
- <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>0</kbd> or click to focus sidebar
- Type "foo" in quick succession to go to the directory (in the current directory) starting with `/fo?o?/`, if it exists

data.title: Feature request: allow extension developers to add items to menu
data.body: I'd be surprised if this hasn't come up before, but if it has I haven't been able to find it. It would be extremely nice if extensions had the ability to create menus, both on the top of the screen as well as adding items to the context menu. This could be controlled through a separate .json file or by adding a section to the `contributes` section of `package.json`.

data.title: Can't select warning messages to copy to clipboard
data.body: - VSCode Version: 0.10.11 - OS Version: Mac OS X El Capitan Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create a file that has an error or warning in it (eg. an improperly formatted JSON file) 2. Make sure the appropriate language mode for the file is selected 3. Use `F8` keyboard shortcut to navigate between warnings and errors 4. Try to select, and copy-paste text from a warning or error message. 5. Notice that the text selection cursor appears, when hovering over the message, but you cannot actually select the text. This prevents the standard "copy" command from being invoked (`CMD + C`) Cheers, Trevor Sullivan Microsoft MVP: PowerShell
